The proximity of superconductivity can have various effects on the Kondo effect in quantum dot systems. Some of the effects include:

1. Suppression of the Kondo effect: If the energy gap of the superconductivity becomes larger than the relevant Kondo temperature, the Kondo effect can be suppressed.

2. Enhancement of the Kondo effect: For quantum dots attached to both superconducting and normal contacts, the superconducting pairing can enhance the Kondo effect.

3. Modification of the Kondo physics: For DQD-based Cooper pair splitters, the superexchange induced by superconductivity tends to suppress both the SU(2) and SU(4) Kondo effects.

4. Emergence of the crossed Andreev reflections (CAR) exchange mechanism: The presence of superconductivity induces non-local pairing in quantum dots, leading to the CAR exchange mechanism, which can significantly modify the low-temperature transport behavior of correlated hybrid nanostructures. 

Overall, the proximity of superconductivity can play a crucial role in altering the Kondo effect in quantum dot systems.
